mxCell.value: 3. Service checks request body to determine which flow to execute (credential or refresh token login). If no credentials are found, service responds with failure to authenticate (401).

5. Service takes password from request body, concatenates salt from Account, and hashes it. Result is compared with hash from Account. If they don't match, service responds to client with failure to authenticate (401).
6. Service generates unique refresh token and PersistentSession entry. ID token (JWT) is generated with PersistentSession ID and creation time (current time) embedded in the payload.
4. Service fetches Account from database. Username in request body is used to query via name. If no Account exists with given username, service responds to client with failure to authenticate (401).
1. Client makes POST request to /api/login. Body contains credentials (username and password).
2. Gateway forwards request to account service.
7. Account service responds to client with success (200), embedding refresh token and ID token in body.
3. Service checks request body to determine which flow to execute (credential or refresh token login). Refresh token is found, so refresh token flow starts.
4. Service uses refresh token in request body to query database for PersistentSession. If no match is found or match is expired, service responds to client with failure to authenticate (401).
5. Service generates ID token (JWT) with PersistentSession ID and creation time embedded in the payload.
1. Client makes POST request to /api/login. Body contains refresh token.
2. Gateway forwards request to account service.
6. Account service responds to client with success (200), embedding ID token in body.
3. Service uses refresh token from request body to delete any matching PersistentSession entry from database.
1. Client makes POST request to /api/logout. Body contains refresh token.
2. Gateway forwards request to account service.

3. Service extracts ID token (JWT) from request's authorization header. Token is verified via standard JWT procedures. Service extracts PersistentSession ID. If request does not contain token or verification fails, empty authority object is generated and returned to gateway.
4. Service uses extracted ID to fetch PersistentSession from database. If no entry is found or entry is expired, ID token is considered as invalid and empty authority object is returned to gateway.
5. Service uses Account ID, roles, and creation time (equivalent to login time) of PersistentSession to construct authority object.
2. Gateway forwards request to account service for client identification.
6. Account service returns authority object to gateway.
7. Gateway forwards original request with authority object to original destination.
8. Service uses authority object to determine whether client is authorized to execute request.
4. Service checks authority object to verify that client has at least one of following roles: system, admin, and user. If not, request is denied (401).
5. Service checks login time from authority object. If login time is too old (configurable threshold), request is denied (401).

6. Service queries database for entry specified by request's query parameters. If no such entry exists, service responds with failure (404) for system and admins and access denial (401) for standard users.
7. If only user role exists, service also verifies that Account ID from authority object matches ID of matched entry. If not, request is denied (401).
9. Service purges all PersistentSession entries that correspond to deleted Account entry.
1. Client makes DELETE request to /api/account with ID token in authorization header. Target Account's ID, name, or both are specified as query parameters as such: /api/account?id=123&name=qwer
3. Gateway forwards request with authority object to Account service.
13. Account service responds to client with success (200).
10. Account service publishes message that notifies subscribers of account delete event. Message contains ID of deleted account.
12. Service deletes Profile identified by received Account ID.
11. Profile service (and possibly other services) are subscribed to Account delete event and receive message containing ID of deleted Account.
1. Client makes HTTP request with ID token (JWT) in authorization header.
3. Identification service verifies ID token and extracts PersistentSession ID.
2. Gateway forwards request to identification service.
4. Identification service fetches corresponding PersistentSession from PersistentSession service.
5. Identification service returns UserAccount ID, roles, and creation time of PersistentSession to gateway.
6. Gateway forwards original request with UserAccount ID, roles, and creation time of PersistentSession to appropriate service.
